sect2.title: Gender
sect2.para: The prevalence of OCD OCD is similar for both females and males; however, there are some gender differences in the onset of symptoms, comorbid diagnoses, and subtype or presentation of OCD symptoms. For instance, males have a greater likelihood of symptom onset in childhood perhaps linked to co-occurrence of Tourette or autism, while OCD is more common for females in adolescence and adulthood (Mathes et al., 2019 ). Additionally, males are more likely to present with comorbid tic disorders and females are more likely to present with comorbid excoriation disorder or eating disorders (Mathis et al., 2011 ). Furthermore, females are more likely to present with contamination subtype, whereas males are more likely to present with sexual and symmetry-related obsessions. There are inconclusive findings for gender differences with harm-related obsessions, as many studies report mixed results. There are no reported gender differences in treatment outcomes (for reviews, see Mathis et al., 2011 ; Mathes et al., 2019 ). Considering these findings, it is important that clinicians make note of common presenting subtypes for each gender when assessing and evaluating individuals for OCD.

sect2.title: Age
Race and Ethnicity
Religion and Spirituality
sect2.para: Religious and spiritual backgrounds can shape the presentation of certain domains of OCD symptoms symptoms . For individuals who experience obsessions or compulsions related to their religious or spiritual beliefs, intrusive thoughts can be associated with specific customs of their religion, such as scripture or beliefs regarding the afterlife. For example, an individual who identifies as Muslim and is from an Islam-based faith may engage in contamination-related compulsions in addition to washing rituals during prayer that other Muslims follow. When assessing children experiencing OCD related to religious thoughts, it can be especially helpful to gather information from their parents to distinguish normative practices within their faith community from obsessions and compulsions. For example, a child from a Christian faith may have the urge to compulsively pray outside of what is typical for the family or what is suggested at church.

As an individual’s religion or faith can be an influential part of their identity, they may wish to enlist support from religious leaders or healers within their community. There can be a risk for mental health providers to attempt to control or suppress an individual’s religious or spiritual beliefs if they perceive that the religion is at the root of the individual’s intrusive thoughts or is exacerbating OCD OCD symptoms (Williams et al., 2020 ). It is important that clinicians assess and treat OCD while being mindful and respectful of the confines of the individual’s religious beliefs/traditions. When necessary, it can be helpful for clinicians to defer to the client’s religious leaders or healers to identify normative practices for the religion. Although it is not required for clinicians to be experts in specific religions for successful OCD treatment, increasing knowledge on basic customs and traditions within the religion can increase rapport and assist with differentiating normative cultural/religious practices from compulsions (Williams et al., 2020 ).
